Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: The client’s future is heavily dependent on the outcome of a critical trial
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, the scent of my mother’s special holiday stew filling the air, laughter echoing from the living room where my family gathered for our annual tradition. My phone buzzed again—another message from my client, desperate for reassurance before tomorrow’s trial. As a child, I was expected to be present, to honor our family’s customs, to help set the table and share stories, just as I had every year. But as an advocate, I knew my client’s future hinged on my preparation tonight; the trial was in the morning, and there were still documents to review, arguments to refine. My father caught my eye, smiling, expecting me to join the toast. My heart twisted. I wanted to be the devoted child, but the weight of my client’s trust pressed on me. I felt torn, the warmth of family pulling me one way, the gravity of my professional duty pulling me another. I stared at my phone, then at my family, feeling the impossible tension between who I was to them and who I needed to be for someone else.
